definition: The world’s most comprehensive and broadly adopted cloud platform.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: A database that contains reinsurance information you can use to derive and calculate market shares. To produce the database, A.M. Best compiles data from the year-end annual reports of more than 2,000 companies.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A reinsurance program in which the ceding company is indemnified for the portion of the loss that exceeds the limit of its own retention per event.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A network of remote servers that operate as a single ecosystem.
author: Maria Flores

definition: Describes applications designed to run on the cloud, rather than on-premises networks.
author: Ben Carter

definition: A group of districts within a state in India, used by the Indian crop insurance market.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: The portion of the losses to a layer covered by a reinsurer. Where coinsurance and gross/net participation are all specified, the participation % is applied to the treaty’s share of coinsured losses.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: A simple text file that stores data in columns separated by commas.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: The loss a company is estimated to have from an event, excluding any program/treaty terms.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: Damage factors applied to catastrophe models customize losses based on the experiences of a company.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: The amount of loss retained by the insured; also called aggregate retention.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A multiplicative factor used to account for the effects of short-term inflation in the prices of labor and materials following a catastrophe.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A list of specific policies and locations, with location attributes such as construction/occupancy, year built, and replacement cost by coverage. Contrasts with aggregate exposure.
author: Maria Flores

definition: An encrypted file that contains company losses by geographic area and line of business for each simulated event.
author: Ben Carter

definition: A catastrophic event with predefined characteristics, typically used to assess potential losses. There is no probability distribution for deterministic events.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: The process of distributing aggregate exposure data from a coarse resolution to a finer resolution; more suitable for detailed catastrophe modeling.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: The set of loss files used in a detailed or aggregate loss analysis.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: A variable that describes an aspect of an event.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: A set of probabilities and return periods that appear in loss analysis results. Also see exceedance probability curve.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: Item of value at risk (e.g., a house); unit of measurement for risk.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A discrete set of related exposure entities, such as locations and contracts, and their related financial terms.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A compiled set of summary information about a group of exposures, either an exposure set or an exposure view.
author: Maria Flores

definition: A user-defined logical view of one or more exposure sets, with optional filters.
author: Ben Carter

definition: The parameters, such as limits and deductibles, specified in an insurance policy that define the conditions under which the insurer will pay some or all the loss. These may be defined at various levels such as contract, layer, and location, and may apply to its entirety or to specific perils and/or coverages.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: The side of a volcano.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: The vertical distance between where a fault rupture originates and the earth's surface.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: A deductible that is only applied if the loss exceeds a specified minimum level.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: A security update for the Microsoft SQL server.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: The latitude and longitude values and the resolution associated with an individual risk used for modeling in catastrophe modeling.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: The total loss due to an event before applying financial terms such as limits and deductibles.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A factor or condition that can increase or decrease the probability or severity of a loss from an insured peril (for example, proximity to the coast).
author: Maria Flores

definition: The limits and deductibles that apply to individual locations and risks.
author: Ben Carter

definition: An attribute of a contract that describes the class of business. These can be user-defined or based on industry definitions such as residential, commercial, auto, etc.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: A benchmark rate that some of the world's leading banks charge each other for short-term loans.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: Loss files contain data generated to predict losses due to a particular catastrophe.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: Company losses generated from a market share analysis on ALERT™ event sets by comparing company loss file losses with the ILF to estimate company market share.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: The proportion of the industry written by a company, often expressed as percentages by line of business and area/subarea.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: A user-specified adjustment factor that applies to the losses for a single program.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A program term associated with occurrence limit.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A software development approach in which single-function modules form the basis of the application or deliverable.
author: Maria Flores

definition: The deductible that is applied if the coverage or site deductible is less than the specified minimum level.
author: Ben Carter

definition: The number of property exposures at risk. For workers' compensation exposures, this is the employee count.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: An attribute that indicates how a property is used, such as single-family residence or for retail trade.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: A server that is reserved for use by a single entity, such as a business, and that resides in a location managed by that entity.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: Information and instructions available with a software application.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: A standard that provides the industry with a robust, open, and transparent data format with the aim of delivering a common framework for encoding, transmitting, and interpreting data.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: See quota share and surplus share.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A computer programming language that uses queries to request and retrieve data from databases and information systems.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A reinsurance program where the reinsurer is responsible for the same percentage of every risk.
author: Maria Flores

definition: Estimated likelihood of a loss of a given size occurring within a given time frame.
author: Ben Carter

definition: See industry loss maximum.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: An area where a volcano is rifting or splitting apart. Rock in a rift zone has many cracks and is relatively weak.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: The treaty limit for a single risk or layer. The risk limit value applies only to a single risk or layer.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: A simple, non-topological vector format for storing the geometric location and attribute information of geographic features.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: A cloud application and infrastructure environment that serves a single client.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: A software licensing model in which access to the software is provided on a subscription basis, with the software being located on external servers rather than on servers located in-house.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A source program (parent) associated with a subject program (child).
author: Samuel Greene

definition: The extent to which the losses at two locations behave similarly due to their spatial proximity.
author: Maria Flores

definition: An insurance industry term short for individual location-level (spot) facultative (fac) reinsurance. See facultative reinsurance.
author: Ben Carter

definition: A programming language for storing and processing information in a relational database.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: A type of layer condition that applies to a subset of locations within a policy. Sublimits are often used in high-hazard areas to limit losses for locations that fall within them.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: The maximum amount that an insurance company is obligated to cover in the event of a covered loss.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: A catalog of events that reflects hurricane risk under average climate conditions.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: An agreement for federal crop insurance that consists of a set of contracts between the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and private companies. The contracts identify expense reimbursements and risk-sharing by the government on eligible crops.
author: Kenji Tanaka

definition: The percentage of insurable properties actually insured.
author: Aisha Khan

definition: A company loss set or an exposure set.
author: Samuel Greene

definition: A catalog of probabilistic events that assumes that the annual probability of a characteristic earthquake occurring on a fault increases with the time elapsed since the previous such earthquake.
author: Maria Flores

definition: A standard for identifying servers, printers, and other resources on a network, allowing a consistent access to these resources across different systems.
author: Ben Carter

definition: A category which allow you to classify companies and programs using criteria that are meaningful and useful to your specific needs.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition:
Glossary management software for teams. Features include entry drafts, approval workflow, perspectives, and collaborative comments.

See also: glossary entry, curator.
author: Maria Flores

definition: Preliminary version of a glossary entry that can be edited and reviewed before approval. Supports rich text formatting and comments.
author: Ben Carter

definition: A term and its definition in the system. Entries may be linked to perspectives and managed by curators.
author: Sofia Rossi

definition: Process ensuring new or edited entries are reviewed by curators before becoming official. See curator and entry draft.
author: Leo Schmidt

definition: Organizes glossary entries by domain or viewpoint, such as EES and Tools.
author: Chloe Dubois

definition: User responsible for reviewing and approving glossary entries within a perspective.
author: Ivan Petrov

definition: System for feedback and collaboration on entry drafts and glossary entries.
author: Aisha Khan
